title: Valentines Day Consumer Data
text:
In this project, I analyze consumer spending on Valentines Day using the Tidy Tuesday Valentine’s Day survey data from the National Retail Federation (NRF) Valentine’s Day Data Center. The data set provides detailed information on how consumers celebrate Valentine’s Day annually for over a decade (2010 - 2022) and uses interactive charts to explore a demographic break down on both spending and gift type. This data set is ideal for exploring and understanding relationships in consumer spending.

gifts_age <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-02-13/gifts_age.csv')


library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidytuesdayR)

ggplot(gifts_age, aes(x = Age, y = SpendingCelebrating, group = 1)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue", size = 3) +  
  geom_line(color = "red", linewidth = 1) + 
  labs(
    title = "Percentage of People Spending Money on Valentine's Day by Age",
    x = "Age Group",
    y = "Percentage Spending (%)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))








Here I created a scatterplot to visualizes the percentage of people spending money on Valentine’s Day across different age groups. The x-axis represents various age groups, while the y-axis indicates the percentage of individuals in each group who report spending money on the holiday. A red line is used to connect the points, highlighting the trend in spending participation across age demographics.
This visualization helps identify spending habits among different generations, showing whether younger or older individuals are more likely to participate financially in Valentine’s Day celebrations.
Data Source:
https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/infinator/happy-valentines-day-2022
Author: TidyTuesday Project
This data was sourced from the TidyTuesday project, which provides weekly data challenges for the R community. Specifically, the dataset focuses on consumer spending on valentine’s Day:
- The dataset originates from the National Retail Federation’s annual Valentine’s Day surveys and last updated November 2024.
- Data spans from 2010 to 2022 and examines spending habits by age group.
- This dataset provides insights into planned spending on different types of gifts and overall spending participation.

title: About Me
text:
Rhyan Goozh


Welcome to my website! I am a student at Pomona College (’27) majoring in Economics and minoring in Data Science. At Pomona I am an Associate Consultant for Pomona Consulting Group and the Finance Director for Party With a Purpose Dance Marathon Club. I also play on the Pomona Woman’s Varsity Lacrosse team.

title: Text Analysis
text:
In this project, I analyzed the Netflix Movies and TV Shows dataset to explore trends and insights into potential Netflix consumer engagement strategy. This dataset, sourced from Kaggle and made available through TidyTuesday, provides information on titles, genres, release years, duration, and descriptions.

netflix_titles <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-04-20/netflix_titles.csv')


library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidytuesdayR)
library(stringr)
library(plotly)
library(dplyr)


Question 1: What are the most commonly produced genres on Netflix?

# Convert listed genres to lowercase
netflix_titles <- netflix_titles |> 
  mutate(listed_in = str_to_lower(listed_in))


# Split genres into individual rows
genre_trends <- netflix_titles |> 
  separate_rows(listed_in, sep = ", ") |> 
  count(listed_in, sort = TRUE) |> 
  rename(primary_genre = listed_in, total_count = n)


# Keep only the top 10 genres
top_10_genres <- genre_trends |> 
  slice_max(total_count, n = 10)


# Bar plot with genre names on x-axis
genre_plot <- ggplot(top_10_genres, aes(x = reorder(primary_genre, total_count), y = total_count)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue") +
  coord_flip() +  
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Most Commonly Produced Genres on Netflix",
    x = "Genre",
    y = "Count"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

print(genre_plot)










Question 2: Is there a relationship between movie length and release year?

# Convert duration to numeric values (for movies only) and exclude any shows with "season" in duration
netflix_titles <- netflix_titles |> 
  mutate(
    # Extract movie duration, excluding anything that has the word 'season' in it using negative lookahead
    movie_length = as.numeric(str_extract(duration, "^(?!.*seasons).*\\d+"))
  )

# Filter to only movies and ensure there are valid movie lengths and release years
movie_data <- netflix_titles |> 
  filter(
    type == "Movie" & 
    !is.na(movie_length) & 
    !is.na(release_year) &
    movie_length > 0
  )

# Check the first few rows of filtered movie data
head(movie_data)

# A tibble: 6 × 13
  show_id type  title director      cast  country date_added release_year rating
  <chr>   <chr> <chr> <chr>         <chr> <chr>   <chr>             <dbl> <chr> 
1 s2      Movie 7:19  Jorge Michel… Demi… Mexico  December …         2016 TV-MA 
2 s3      Movie 23:59 Gilbert Chan  Tedd… Singap… December …         2011 R     
3 s4      Movie 9     Shane Acker   Elij… United… November …         2009 PG-13 
4 s5      Movie 21    Robert Luket… Jim … United… January 1…         2008 PG-13 
5 s7      Movie 122   Yasir Al Yas… Amin… Egypt   June 1, 2…         2019 TV-MA 
6 s8      Movie 187   Kevin Reynol… Samu… United… November …         1997 R     
# ℹ 4 more variables: duration <chr>, listed_in <chr>, description <chr>,
#   movie_length <dbl>

# Scatter plot of movie length vs. release year with trend line
length_vs_year_plot <- ggplot(movie_data, aes(x = release_year, y = movie_length)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "darkred") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between Movie Length and Release Year",
    x = "Release Year",
    y = "Movie Length (minutes)"
  )
print(length_vs_year_plot)










How many titles on Netflix use “The” in it?

the_count <- sum(str_detect(netflix_titles[["title"]], "\\bthe\\b"))
the_count

[1] 558


Analysis on Tables/Plots:
This dataset provides insights into Netflix’s content strategy by analyzing trends in genre production and movie lengths. The findings highlight how Netflix has adapted its catalog over time based on consumer preferences and market demands. The analysis focuses on two key aspects: the most commonly produced genres and the relationship between movie lengths and release years.
My first bar chart displays the top 10 most frequently produced genres on Netflix, with Drama, Comedy, and International Movies and TV shows leading. These genres dominate the platform’s library, suggesting that Netflix has prioritized them in response to audience demand. Netflix’s heavy investment in Drama indicates a strategic response to consumer preference for emotionally engaging narratives, while Comedy’s strong presence suggests sustained demand for lighthearted entertainment. The high production of International entertainment reflects the growing interest in informative, worldly-based content, likely driven by increased global accessibility, audience demand for diverse storytelling, and Netflix’s expansion into non-English markets to attract and retain subscribers worldwide.
The scatter plot reveals a slight decreasing trend in movie lengths from 1940 to 2020. This suggests a shift toward shorter films, potentially reflecting changing viewer habits, such as a preference for more concise content in the streaming era. Given Netflix’s data-driven approach, this trend likely influenced its decision to produce shorter movies, catering to modern audiences who favor engaging, time-efficient content.
To make the trend clearer, the second plot groups movie lengths by decade, reducing the noise from individual data points in the scatter plot. This broader view highlights more distinct shifts over time, making it easier to see how Netflix’s production aligns with evolving consumer preferences.
Data Source: Netflix Movies and TV Shows Dataset https://www.kaggle.com/shivamb/netflix-shows?select=netflix_titles.csv
Author: Shivam Bansal
This dataset, sourced from Kaggle, originates from Flixable, a third-party Netflix search engine. It contains information about movies and TV shows available on Netflix since 2019, including:

Attributes such as title, genre, language, release year, and rating.
Insights into patterns related to content production, genre trends, and the evolution of media consumption.
Integration with external datasets like IMDB and Rotten Tomatoes for deeper analysis.
The data was last updated on Kaggle by Shivam Bansal.

title: Permutation Tests
text:
The analysis explores whether NHL players are disproportionately born in certain months compared to the general Canadian population. Specifically, we will test if players born in the first quarter (January-March) are overrepresented.
Our research question is: Are NHL players born significantly more often in the first quarter of the year than the general Canadian population?
Hypotheses:

Null hypothesis (H0): The proportion of NHL players born in the first quarter of the year is the same as the proportion of Canadians born in the first quarter.
Alternative hypothesis (H1): The proportion of NHL players born in the first quarter of the year is significantly higher than the proportion of Canadians born in the first quarter.

We will conduct a right-tailed permutation test to test this hypothesis. If the p-value is below the significance level (0.05), we will reject the null hypothesis. Otherwise, we fail to reject it.

install.packages("tidytuesdayR", repos = "https://cran.rstudio.com/")


The downloaded binary packages are in
    /var/folders/g9/867pm4511654b9qpdd1d7k4c0000gn/T//Rtmpj1r2HS/downloaded_packages

library(tidytuesdayR)

# Load the data for January 9, 2024
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2024-01-09')


library(dplyr)
library(lubridate)
library(readr)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(purrr)
library(tidyr)
set.seed(123)


# Importing datasets I will analyze 
canada_births_1991_2022 <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-01-09/canada_births_1991_2022.csv')
nhl_player_births <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-01-09/nhl_player_births.csv')
nhl_rosters <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-01-09/nhl_rosters.csv')
nhl_teams <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-01-09/nhl_teams.csv')


# Extracting the birth month and filtering relevant data from NHL dataset
nhl_player_births <- nhl_player_births |> 
  mutate(birth_month = month(as.Date(birth_date, format = "%Y-%m-%d"))) |> 
  filter(!is.na(birth_month))

# Preprocessing Canadian data for birth months in the general population and removing NA values
canada_births_1991_2022 <- canada_births_1991_2022 |> 
  filter(!is.na(month))


# Summary Statistics
# Calculating the proportion of players and population born in the first quarter (Jan-Mar)

# NHL first quarter proportion
nhl_first_quarter <- nhl_player_births |> 
  filter(birth_month %in% c(1, 2, 3)) |> 
  summarize(first_quarter_prop = n() / nrow(nhl_player_births))

# Canadian first quarter proportion
canadian_first_quarter <- canada_births_1991_2022 |> 
  filter(month %in% c(1, 2, 3)) |>  # 'month' column in the Canada dataset
  summarize(first_quarter_prop = n() / nrow(canada_births_1991_2022))

# View results
nhl_first_quarter

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  first_quarter_prop
               <dbl>
1              0.298

canadian_first_quarter

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  first_quarter_prop
               <dbl>
1               0.25



# Summary Statistics
# Plot and visualize the distributions of birth months for NHL players and the Canadian population

# Plot for NHL players
ggplot(nhl_player_births, aes(x = birth_month)) +  # Use 'birth_month' from nhl_player_births
  geom_bar(fill = "skyblue", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Birth Month Distribution of NHL Players", x = "Month", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()







# Plot for Canadian population
ggplot(canada_births_1991_2022, aes(x = month)) +  # Use 'month' from canada_births_1991_2022
  geom_bar(fill = "orange", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Birth Month Distribution of Canadian Population", x = "Month", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()









# Define a function to simulate the birthdate distribution under the null hypothesis
# Permutation test function to simulate the birth month difference under the null hypothesis
perm_test <- function(nhl_data, canadian_data, n_perm = 5000) {
  observed_diff <- nhl_data |> 
    filter(birth_month %in% c(1, 2, 3)) |> 
    nrow() / nrow(nhl_data) - 
    canadian_data |> 
    filter(month %in% c(1, 2, 3)) |> 
    nrow() / nrow(canadian_data)
  
  perm_diffs <- map_dbl(1:n_perm, ~ {
    shuffled_nhl <- nhl_data |> 
      mutate(birth_month = sample(birth_month))  # Shuffle the NHL birth months
    mean(shuffled_nhl$birth_month %in% c(1, 2, 3)) - 
      mean(canadian_data$month %in% c(1, 2, 3))  # Use 'month' in Canadian data
  })
  
  tibble(observed = observed_diff, permuted = perm_diffs)
}

# Running the permutation test
perm_results <- perm_test(nhl_player_births, canada_births_1991_2022)


# Calculate p-value
p_value <- sum(perm_results$permuted >= perm_results$observed) / length(perm_results$permuted)
p_value

[1] 1

# Function to calculate confidence intervals for the permutation test results
calculate_ci <- function(perm_results, alpha = 0.05) {
  lower <- quantile(perm_results$permuted, probs = alpha / 2)
  upper <- quantile(perm_results$permuted, probs = 1 - alpha / 2)
  c(lower, upper)
}

conf_int <- calculate_ci(perm_results)
conf_int

      2.5%      97.5% 
0.04844229 0.04844229 



# Plot the permutation test results
# Plotting the null distribution and observed difference
ggplot(perm_results, aes(x = permuted)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.01, fill = "skyblue", color = "black", alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = observed), color = "red", linetype = "dashed", size = 1.2) +
  labs(title = "Permutation Test Results: NHL vs Canadian Birth Months", x = "Proportion Difference", y = "Frequency") +
  theme_minimal()








Conclusion:
The plot displays the distribution of permuted differences in birth month proportions between NHL players and the general Canadian population. The red dashed line represents the observed difference between the two groups. From the permutation test, we calculated the observed difference in proportions as 0.0484. The p-value from the test is 1, which is greater than the significance level of 0.05, so we fail to reject the null hypothesis.
The 95% confidence interval for the difference in proportions is [0.0484, 0.0484], meaning that all permuted values are identical, which suggests no variation in the results. Therefore, based on this analysis, we conclude that NHL players are not significantly more likely to be born in the first quarter of the year compared to the general Canadian population.
However, it’s important to note that the relative age effect (RAE) is a well-documented phenomenon in hockey and other sports, particularly at the youth and junior levels, where players born in the first quarter of the year have a competitive advantage. This effect has been widely recognized and may play a role in creating the perception that NHL players are disproportionately born early in the year. It’s possible that other factors—such as sample size, variations in the dataset, or the specific nature of the NHL player pool—could explain the discrepancy between our findings and what the literature typically reports.
Data Source:
TidyTuesday Dataset – January 9, 2024
Data for this analysis was sourced from the TidyTuesday GitHub repository for the week of January 9, 2024. The datasets contain birthdate information for Canadian populations and NHL players:
Canadian Births (1991-2022): This dataset includes monthly birth counts for Canadian residents from 1991 to 2022. It is available at this link. NHL Player Births: This dataset contains birthdates of NHL players and is available at this link. NHL Rosters: A dataset with NHL team rosters and player information, available at this link. NHL Teams: This dataset contains information about NHL teams, available at this link. The data is up-to-date as of January 2024. All datasets are publicly available via GitHub and were accessed using the tidytuesdayR package.

title: FBI Crime Data
text:
In this project, I analyze agency level crime data across all 50 states using the Tidy Tuesday Agencies From the FBI Crime Data API data set. The data set provides detailed information on law enforcement agencies across all 50 states that have submitted data to the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) program and are displayed on the Crime Data Explorer (CDE). This data set is ideal for exploring trends and understanding the fluidity in crime.

#install.packages("tidytuesdayR")
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2025-02-18')
agencies <- tuesdata$agencies


library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidytuesdayR)

agencies |>
  count(state, agency_type) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = state, y = n, color = agency_type)) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  labs(
    x = "State",
    y = "Number of Agencies",
    title = "Distribution of Law Enforcement Agencies by State and Type",
    color = "Agency Type"
  ) +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5),
    legend.position = "bottom"
    )








Here I created a scatterplot that visualizes the distribution of law enforcement agencies by state and agency type. The x-axis represents the states, while the y-axis displays the number of agencies in each state. Different colors represent different agency types.
This visualization helps identify variations in agency distribution across states and highlights trends in the presence of different law enforcement agency types. It can be useful for understanding the allocation of law enforcement resources and regional differences in agency structures.
Data Source:
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2025/2025-02-18/agencies.csv
Author: TidyTuesday Project
This data was sourced from the TidyTuesday project, which provides weekly data challenges for the R community. Specifically, the dataset focuses on law enforcement agencies across the U.S.:
- The dataset was last committed on February 18, 2025.
- It includes details on agencies that have submitted data to the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program.
- The dataset provides insights into agency types, geographical distribution, and NIBRS participation.
